author: _shemnon
content: We won't ever delete the special case hashing on type 0 transactions (where the hash trims off the wrapper byte).  All the blocks between Berlin and London will have to be re-validated.  A special hashing rule will live forever.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, a client could decide to just hard code the details of block `n` and not sync history before it, thus not need to actually implement all of the old behavior.

author: sky.cactus
content: One can also imagine a client I implementation where each hard fork coincided with a full client fork (of the source code fork variety) where they essentially have a different codebase for each network hard fork, and they all share a DB and have a mechanism of switching clients on network fork blocks.  Such a client would be able to have clean code for their newer stuff as the latest version wouldn't need to understand legacy blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: Point here being merely that I think technical debt for code that was used in old blocks has a different cost than code necessary to process/handle new blocks/transactions.

author: _shemnon
content:
> Also, a client could decide to just hard code the details of block n and not sync history before it, thus not need to actually implement all of the old behavior.
But they won't.  Weak subjectivity isn't good enough for some people.
